description.p: As the angry mob continues to rain blows against the line of shields before them, a lone human soldier shores up her defenses and prepares for more blows to come. When she finally senses a break in the battle, she unleashes a swinging strike that knocks her attackers to the floor.

With the battle raging all around him, the unarmoured dwarf runs recklessly into the centre of his enemies swinging his greataxe gleefully. He laughs as his foes descend upon him, not knowing that each drop of his blood they draw will only make him stronger.
Raising her sword high into the air, the tiefling warrior weaves into the fray with a triumphant cry. Her enemies lose heart as, with each missed blow, she only seems to cut them down faster.

Vanguards are martial warriors who lead the charge in battle. Many make a living as mercenaries, clearing the way for their weaker allies. Others are soldiers, protecting the free lands of the world from dangerous threats. And some are lone warriors who actively seek out and relish the thrill of battle.

The most important thing to remember when making a vanguard character is that they have an eagerness to enter any battle, no matter how small or unimportant. They spend their lives seeking out a worthy challenge, whether it be travelling the world looking for the strongest adversaries or leading the charge in a war. They are only content when fighting against the greatest odds. Are you a retired soldier who has turned to a life of adventure to find a challenge? Have you been sent from your lord on a special mission?
As avid combatants, vanguards may belong to any alignment. Consider how your alignment may have affected your path until now, including the masters or causes you have fought for.
You can make a vanguard quickly by following these suggestions. First, Strength and Constitution should be your highest scores. Second, choose the soldier background.
As a vanguard, you gain the following class features.

ul.li: Hit Points at 1st Level: 10 + your Constitution modifier
Hit Points at Higher Levels: 1d10 (or 6) + your Constitution modifier per class level after 1st
Skills: Choose two from Acrobatics, Athletics, History, Insight, Intimidation, Perception, Persuasion, and Survival.

description.p: You start with the following equipment, in addition to the equipment granted by your background:

ul.li: (a) a martial weapon and a shield or (b) two martial weapons
(a) five javelins or (b) any simple melee weapon
(a) chain mail or (b) chain shirt, short bow, and 20 arrows or (c) leather armour, longbow, and 20 arrows

setters.set: A martial warrior that gains intensity the longer a battle rages on.

description.p: As a vanguard, you have unparalleled control over your own body. You gain proficiency in either the Dexterity (Acrobatics) or Strength (Athletics) skill. If you are already proficient in your chosen skill, your proficiency bonus is doubled for this skill check.

The longer a battle lasts, the stronger you find yourself becoming. Choosing to become a vanguard, you gain a Fervour Count when in combat which increases by 1 when you deal damage, once per round. Whenever you make a successful weapon attack, you may deal additional damage equaling your Fervour Damage roll x Fervour Multiplier of your weapon’s damage type. After using this feature, your Fervour Count is reset to 0.
Your Fervour Count resets to 0 as soon as combat ends. If you do not deal damage in a round, your Fervour Count is reduced by 1. Any damage dealt with Fervour is not doubled on a critical hit.

sheet.description: You gain 1 Fervour Count when you deal damage, {{fervour:times-per-round}} per round. When you make a successful attack, you may deal an additional {{fervour:damage}} x your Fervour Multiplier. After using this, your Ferver Count resets to 0. Your Fervour Count resets to 0 as soon as combat ends. If you do not deal damage in a round, your Fervour Count is reduced by 1. Fervour Damage is not doubled on a critical hit.

You gain 1 Fervour Count when you deal damage, {{fervour:times-per-round}} per round. When you make a successful attack, you may deal an additional {{fervour:damage}} x your Fervour Multiplier. After using this, your Ferver Count resets to 0. Your Fervour Count resets to 0 as soon as combat ends. Fervour Damage is not doubled on a critical hit.

description.p: Seeing the damage they are capable of causing often fuels a vanguard’s attacks further. At 2nd level, if you roll the maximum damage on your damage roll after making a successful weapon attack, you may immediately make another weapon attack of the same type. This may only be used once per turn.

sheet.description: If you roll the maximum damage on your damage roll after making a successful weapon attack, you may immediately make another weapon attack of the same type. This may only be used once per turn.

description.p: At 2nd level, you adopt a particular style of fighting as your specialty. Choose one of the following options. You can’t take a Fighting Style option more than once, even if you later get to choose again.
You gain a +2 bonus to attack rolls you make with ranged weapons.
While you are wearing armour, you gain +1 bonus to AC.
When you are wielding a melee weapon in one hand and no other weapons, you gain a +2 bonus to damage rolls with that weapon.
When you engage in two-weapon fighting, you can add your ability modifier to the damage of the second attack.

Vanguards often find themselves more suited to a particular style of fighting. From 3rd level, you choose to focus on this style and become a more formidable combatant. Now you choose Frenzy Tactics, Guardian Tactics, or Reckless Tactics.
Your choice grants you features at 3rd level and again at 7th, 10th, and 15th level.

When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
Beginning at 5th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

sheet.description: You can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

description.p: Once you have entered a battle, you are not easily deterred from the fight. From 6th level, you may add your Fervour Multiplier to any saving throw. Using this feature immediately sets your Fervour Count to 0.

After being used, this feature cannot be used again until you have finished a long rest. You can use this feature twice between long rests starting at 10th level and three times between long rests starting at 14th level.

Starting at 11th level, you have an almost unstoppable momentum while in combat. Your Fervour Count no longer decreases if you fail to deal damage in a round. Additionally, you may now increase your Fervour Count by dealing damage 1 extra time in a round.
From 14th level, you have seen enough battles to borrow tactics from fellow warriors. You may choose 2 Gambits from another subclass to learn. You can only use one of these Gambits per short rest.

sheet.description: You can use one of the follow gambits.

description.p: With practice, you are always prepared to race into battle. From 18th level, your Fervour Count increases by 2 whenever you have to roll initiative.

sheet.description: Your Fervour Count increases by 2 whenever you have to roll initiative.

description.p: Upon reaching 20th level, you find that you are more focused in battle than at any other time. When you reach maximum Fervour Count, you may use a bonus action to become Battle Focused. For the next minute, any time you use a feature that would normally reset your Fervour Count to 0, it instead reduces it by 2. Additionally, when you take the Attack action on your turn, you may attack three times, instead of twice. This ability can be used once and is replenished on a long rest.

sheet.description: When you reach maximum Fervour Count, you become Battle Focused. For the next minute, any time you use a feature that would normally reset your Fervour Count to 0, it instead reduces it by 2. Additionally, when you take the Attack action on your turn, you may attack three times, instead of twice.

description.p: Frenzy tactics allow the true destructive potential of a combatant to be unlocked. Vanguards using these tactics are extremely dangerous warriors, who are always on the offensive when in a fight. They use their all-out attacks, gaining more power the longer they are allowed to keep striking.
Starting at 3rd level, the blood of your enemies only makes you stronger. You may increase your Fervour Count from dealing damage twice in one round.

Your blows are difficult to avoid, particularly when you have caused a great deal of damage to your enemy. At 3rd level, if you score a critical hit or reduce an enemy to 0HP with a weapon attack, you gain advantage on your next weapon attack.

sheet.description: If you score a critical hit or reduce an enemy to 0HP with a weapon attack, you gain advantage on your next weapon attack.

description.p: From 7th level, you become more effective at striking when you’ve already made a number of successful attacks. You get +1 to all weapon attack rolls and weapon attack damage when your Fervour Count is above 0.

sheet.description: You get +1 to all weapon attack rolls and weapon attack damage when your Fervour Count is above 0.
At Fervour Count 1, you get +1 to all weapon attack rolls and weapon attack damage. This increases to +2 at Fervour Count 2 and +3 at Fervour Count 3 or higher.

description.p: Starting at 7th level, your knowledge of combat allows you to exploit your enemy’s weaknesses. On your turn, you may use your action to perform one of the feats listed below. You may use your Gambits a number of times equal to the value of your Gambit Uses in the Vanguard Table, and all uses are replenished on a short rest.

You attempt to hinder your enemies, making it harder for them to flee from you. You make a weapon attack against a single target within range. On a hit, you deal your normal damage and attempt to knock an enemy up to 2 sizes larger than you prone. The enemy must succeed a Strength saving throw against 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Strength or Dexterity modifier (whichever was used in the weapon attack) or they are knocked prone.

You exploit a weakness in the enemy’s defenses to make it easier for yourself and your allies to target them temporarily. You make a weapon attack against a single target within range. On a hit, you deal your normal damage and the target’s AC is reduced by 2 until the end of your next turn.
You make a final strike before safely fleeing from combat. You may make a single weapon attack and use Disengage as bonus action on your turn.

sheet.description: You may Disengage on your turn after making a single attack as part of your action.

description.p: You relish in bringing death to your enemies. Starting at 10th level, each time an enemy dies on a round that you had damaged it, you regain hit points equal to your Constitution modifier.

sheet.description: Each time an enemy dies on a round that you had damaged it, you regain {{constitution:modifier}} hit points.

description.p: From 15th level, your attacks become even more vicious and difficult to withstand. At Fervour Count 1, you get +1 to all weapon attack rolls and weapon attack damage. This increases to +2 at Fervour Count 2 and +3 at Fervour Count 3 or higher. This feature replaces Mindless Frenzy.

Reckless tactics allow a combatant to punish those who hurt them. Vanguards who use this tactic are known for their recklessness in combat, often running into the fray where they can be of most use. Each time an enemy hurts the vanguard, their strength increases.
Starting at 3rd level, you feed off your pain to become stronger. Your Fervour Count increases by 1 when you take damage, once per round.

sheet.description: Your Fervour Count increases by 1 when you take damage, once per round.

description.p: You have been through a number of battles and come out on top, making you healthier than the average warrior. When you choose this tactic at 3rd level, your hit point maximum is increased by +3 and increases by an additional +1 for each additional level you take in the vanguard class.
From 7th level, you find yourself able to take hits that would defeat most others. All incoming damage is reduced by 2 while your Fervour Count is above 0.

sheet.description: All incoming damage is reduced by 2 while your Fervour Count is above 0.
At Fervour Count 1, all incoming damage is reduced by 2. This increases to 4 at Fervour Count 2 and 8 at Fervour Count 3 or higher.

description.p: Starting at 7th level, your knowledge of combat allows you to exploit your enemy’s weaknesses. On your turn, you may use your action to perform one of the feats listed below. You may use your Gambits a number of times equal to the value of your Gambit Uses in the Vanguard Table, and all uses are replenished on a short rest.

You swing your weapon wildly, attempting to target all enemies within your reach. You make a single weapon attack against all targets within melee weapon range. On a hit, each target takes damage equal to your Strength or Dexterity modifier (whichever was used to make the attack).
You allow yourself a short respite from attacking to embrace the pain of your wounds. You make a single weapon attack and, as a bonus action, replenish your hit points by up to 3 x vanguard level.
You race headfirst into combat, relishing the pain you are about to feel. You may make a single weapon attack and use Dash as bonus action on your turn.

description.p: From 10th level, you are most at home in the centre of the battlefield. Your hit points are increased by your Constitution modifier at the end of your turn provided you are within 10 feet of an enemy and have at least 1 hit point remaining.

sheet.description: Your hit points are increased by {{constitution:modifier}} at the end of your turn provided you are within 10 feet of an enemy and have at least 1 hit point remaining.

description.p: From 15th level, you are able to ignore all but the strongest hits. At Fervour Count 1, all incoming damage is reduced by 2. This increases to 4 at Fervour Count 2 and 8 at Fervour Count 3 or higher. This feature replaces Endurance.

Guardian tactics allow a combatant to draw strength from the failed attacks of others. Vanguards who use this tactic are staunch defenders and focus almost entirely on defensive combat, gaining strength each time the enemy fails to strike them. They typically protect themselves with heavy armour and shields, waiting for a break in the combat to unleash their most powerful strikes.
Starting at 3rd level, every failed strike against you makes you more powerful. Your Fervour Count increases by 1 when an enemy fails to meet your AC with an attack, once per round.

sheet.description: Your Fervour Count increases by 1 when an enemy misses you with an attack, once per round.

description.p: You focus your strikes to best hamper your enemy’s attempts at retaliation. At 3rd level, if you score a critical hit on a weapon attack, the target deals half damage on their next attack against anyone but yourself.

sheet.description: If you score a critical hit on a weapon attack, the target deals half damage on their next attack against anyone but yourself.

description.p: Even the strongest attacks often fail to break through your defenses. From 7th level, your AC increases by +1 when your Fervour Count is above 0.

sheet.description: Your AC increases by +1 when your Fervour Count is above 0.
At Fervour Count 1, your AC increases by +1. This increases to +2 AC at Fervour Count 2 and +3 AC at Fervour Count 3 or higher.

description.p: Starting at 7th level, your knowledge of combat allows you to exploit your enemy’s weaknesses. On your turn, you may use your action to perform one of the feats listed below. You may use your Gambits a number of times equal to the value of your Gambit Uses in the Vanguard Table, and all uses are replenished on a short rest.

You attempt to push a single target away from you. You make a single melee weapon attack against a target within range. On a hit, you deal your normal damage and attempt to knock an enemy up to 2 sizes larger than you backwards. You must make a Strength (Athletics) check contested by the target’s Strength (Athletics) or Dexterity (Acrobatics) check (the target chooses the ability to use). If you win the contest, the target is pushed away from you. If the target is up to 1 size larger than you, it is pushed back 10 feet. If the target is 2 sizes larger than you, it is only pushed back 5 feet.

You attempt to draw the ire of your enemy, forcing it to attack you instead of your allies. You make a weapon attack against a single target within range. On a hit, the target has disadvantage on all attacks against creatures other than yourself until the start of your next turn.
Eager not to be hit, you shore up your defenses and ready yourself. You may make a single weapon attack and use Dodge as bonus action on your turn.
